user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SelectFdAdd:
```c
int32 OS_SelectFdAdd(OS_FdSet *Set, osal_id_t objid)
{
    int32        return_code;
    osal_index_t local_id;

    /* check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(Set);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM, objid, &local_id);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * Sets the bit in the uint8 object_ids array that corresponds
         * to the local_id where local_id >> 3 determines the array element,
         * and the mask/shift sets the bit within that element.
         */
        Set->object_ids[local_id >> 3] |= 1 << (local_id & 0x7);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SelectFdAdd:
typedef struct
{
    uint8 object_ids[(OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES + 7) / 8];
} OS_FdSet
...
typedef uint32 osal_index_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t object_id, osal_index_t *ArrayIndex)
{
    uint32         max_id;
    uint32         obj_index;
    osal_objtype_t actual_type;
    int32          return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(ArrayIndex);

    obj_index   = OS_ObjectIdToSerialNumber_Impl(object_id);
    actual_type = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(object_id);

    /*
     * If requested by the caller, enforce that the ID is of the correct type.
     * If the caller passed OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED, then anything is allowed.
     */
    if (idtype != OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED && actual_type != idtype)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERR_INVALID_ID;
    }
    else
    {
        max_id = OS_GetMaxForObjectType(actual_type);
        if (max_id == 0)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INVALID_ID;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            *ArrayIndex = OSAL_INDEX_C(obj_index % max_id);
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM 0x06
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No calls to any of the <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) appear in the provided code. MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 specifically concerns use of the string handling functions from <string.h> and accesses beyond the bounds of objects referenced by their pointer parameters. Since the target function and the related snippets do not invoke any <string.h> routines, there are no code fragments relevant to Rule 21.17 to investigate.

Notes (not for Rule 21.17):
- The write to Set->object_ids[local_id >> 3] could potentially be out-of-bounds if the computed local_id range does not match the array size; however this is not related to Rule 21.17 because it does not involve <string.h> functions. Validation of that potential array-bounds issue should be done against other relevant MISRA rules (array bounds, index validation), not Rule 21.17.
- The pointer check OS_CHECK_POINTER(Set) ensures Set is non-NULL, but again this does not involve <string.h> usage.
